Species Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width  # create formatted data and value data d_value <- copy(data) d_formatted <- copy(data)  # we work with d_value to identify which cells should be colored # we save the colors in a matrix called "css_style_matrix" css_style_matrix <- splstyle::htmltable_css_style_matrix(d_value)  # set some of the third column to have a red background rows <- which(d_value[[3]] > 4) if(length(rows) > 0) css_style_matrix[rows,3] <- splstyle::htmltable_css_background_red  # set some of the fourth column to have a blue background according to risk level # risk level 1 rows <- 1:nrow(d_value) if(length(rows) > 0) css_style_matrix[rows,4] <- splstyle::htmltable_css_risk_1_5(1, palette = "blue")  # risk level 3 rows <- which(d_value[[4]] > 1.3) if(length(rows) > 0) css_style_matrix[rows,4] <- splstyle::htmltable_css_risk_1_5(3, palette = "blue")  # risk level 5 rows <- which(d_value[[4]] > 1.5) if(length(rows) > 0) css_style_matrix[rows,4] <- splstyle::htmltable_css_risk_1_5(5, palette = "blue")  # set some of the fifth column to have a red background according to risk level # risk level 1 rows <- 1:nrow(d_value) if(length(rows) > 0) css_style_matrix[rows,5] <- splstyle::htmltable_css_risk_1_5(1, palette = "red")  # risk level 2 rows <- which(d_value[[5]] > 0.1) if(length(rows) > 0) css_style_matrix[rows,5] <- splstyle::htmltable_css_risk_1_5(2, palette = "red")  # risk level 3 rows <- which(d_value[[5]] > 0.2) if(length(rows) > 0) css_style_matrix[rows,5] <- splstyle::htmltable_css_risk_1_5(3, palette = "red")   # risk level 4 rows <- which(d_value[[5]] > 0.3) if(length(rows) > 0) css_style_matrix[rows,5] <- splstyle::htmltable_css_risk_1_5(4, palette = "red")  # risk level 5 rows <- which(d_value[[5]] > 0.4) if(length(rows) > 0) css_style_matrix[rows,5] <- splstyle::htmltable_css_risk_1_5(5, palette = "red")   # format the data nicely inside d_formatted # set columns 2-3 as numeric with 0 decimal places d_formatted[, Sepal.Length := splstyle::format_nor_num_0(Sepal.Length)] d_formatted[, Sepal.Width := splstyle::format_nor_num_0(Sepal.Width)]  # set columns 4 as numeric with 1 decimal places d_formatted[, Petal.Length := splstyle::format_nor_num_1(Petal.Length)]  # set columns 5 as percentage with 1 decimal places d_formatted[, Petal.Width := splstyle::format_nor_perc_1(100*Petal.Width)]  setnames(   d_formatted,   c("","Sepal length", "Sepal width", "Petal length", "Petal width (%)") )  # now combine d_formatted (contains the text in each cell) # and the css_style_matrix (contains the colors of each cell) tab <- splstyle::htmltable_quick_style(d_formatted, css_style_matrix = css_style_matrix) %>%   htmlTable::htmlTable(     rnames = FALSE,     align = "|l|c|c|c|c|",     align.header = "|l|c|c|c|c|",     align.cgroup = "|l|c|c|c|c|",     spacer.celltype = "skip",     caption = "This is a caption"   )  # you can use this function to interactively test out your table # splstyle::view_html(tab) cat(tab)

Species Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width  wb <- openxlsx::createWorkbook() openxlsx::addWorksheet(wb, "data")  # adding custom titles openxlsx::writeData(   wb,   "data",   x = "data",   x = data,   startCol = 1,   startRow = 2,   colNames = FALSE )  # add styles # title style openxlsx::addStyle(   wb,   sheet = "data",   style = splstyle::excel_style_title,   rows = 1,   cols = 1:10,   gridExpand = T,   stack = T )  # set columns 2-3 as numeric with 0 decimal places openxlsx::addStyle(   wb,   sheet = "data",   style = splstyle::excel_style_num_0,   rows = 2:100,   cols = 2:3,   gridExpand = T,   stack = T )  # set columns 4 as numeric with 1 decimal places openxlsx::addStyle(   wb,   sheet = "data",   style = splstyle::excel_style_num_1,   rows = 2:100,   cols cols = 5,   gridExpand = T,   stack = T )  # set some of the third column to have a red background # you may also use the function splstyle::excel_style_background_yellow # these are just shortcuts for # splstyle::excel_style_risk_1_5(3, palette = "red") # splstyle::excel_style_risk_1_5(5, palette = "red") rows <- 1 + which(data[[3]] > 4) if(length(rows) > 0) openxlsx::addStyle(   wb,   sheet = "data",   style = splstyle::excel_style_background_red,   rows = rows,   cols = 3,   gridExpand = T,   stack = T )  # set some of the fourth column to have a blue background according to risk level # risk level 1 rows <- 1 + 1:ncol(data) if(length(rows) > 0) openxlsx::addStyle(   wb,   sheet = "data",   style = splstyle::excel_style_risk_1_5(1, palette = "blue"),   rows = rows,   cols = 4,   gridExpand = T,   stack = T )  # risk level 3 rows <- 1 + which(data[[4]] > 1.3) if(length(rows) > 0) openxlsx::addStyle(   wb,   sheet = "data",   style = splstyle::excel_style_risk_1_5(3, palette = title: Epicurves
text: generally start linelist dataset (make sure data.table!). now: Convert data.table (case isn’t already) Aggregate daily data (dataset doesn’t contain days 0 cases) Create ‘skeleton’ dataset contains days first last day Merge two datasets together (now dataset contains days 0 cases) Fill ‘missing’ N’s 0 (dates came skeleton dataset) can also create weekly dataset:

title: Epicurves
text: Daily epicurve county01  Weekly epicurve county01  Weekly epicurve vertical x-axis labels
code: q <- ggplot(d[location_code=="county03"], aes(x = date, y = N)) q <- q + geom_col(fill = splstyle::base_color, width = 0.8) q <- q + scale_x_date("Date") q <- q + scale_y_continuous("Number of reported cases",   breaks = splstyle::pretty_breaks(5),   expand = expansion(mult = c(0, 0.1)) ) q <- q + labs(title = "Epicurve from 2018-01-01 to 2018-02-20") q <- q + labs(caption = fhi_caption()) q <- q + splstyle::theme_fhi_lines_horizontal() q q <- ggplot(w[location_code=="county03"], aes(x = isoyearweek, y = N)) q <- q + geom_col(fill = splstyle::base_color, width = 0.8) q <- q + scale_x_discrete("Isoweek") q <- q + scale_y_continuous("Number of reported cases",   breaks = splstyle::pretty_breaks(5),   expand = expansion(mult = c(0, 0.1)) ) q <- q + labs(title = "Epicurve from 2018-01-01 to 2018-02-20") q <- q + labs(caption = fhi_caption()) q <- q + splstyle::theme_fhi_lines_horizontal() q q <- ggplot(w, aes(x = isoyearweek, y = N)) q <- q + geom_col(fill = splstyle::base_color, width = 0.8) q <- q + scale_x_discrete("Isoweek") q <- q + scale_y_continuous("Number of reported cases",   breaks = splstyle::pretty_breaks(5),   expand = expansion(mult = c(0, 0.1)) ) q <- q + labs(title = "Epicurve from 2018-01-01 to 2018-02-20") q <- q + labs(caption = fhi_caption()) q <- q + splstyle::theme_fhi_lines_horizontal() q <- q + splstyle::set_x_axis_vertical() q

title: Epicurves
text: multiple geographical areas, use function lemon::facet_rep_wrap create multiple epicurves. Daily epicurve geographical areas vertical x-axis labels  Weekly epicurve vertical x-axis labels
code: q <- ggplot(d, aes(x = date, y = N)) q <- q + geom_col(fill = splstyle::base_color, width = 0.8) q <- q + lemon::facet_rep_wrap(~location_code, repeat.tick.labels = "y") q <- q + splstyle::scale_fill_fhi("Location",palette="primary") q <- q + scale_x_date("Date") q <- q + scale_y_continuous("Number of reported cases",   breaks = splstyle::pretty_breaks(5),   expand = expansion(mult = c(0, 0.1)) ) q <- q + labs(title = "Epicurve from 2018-01-01 to 2018-02-20") q <- q + labs(caption = fhi_caption()) q <- q + splstyle::theme_fhi_lines_horizontal() q <- q + splstyle::set_x_axis_vertical() q q <- ggplot(d, aes(x = isoyearweek, y = N)) q <- q + geom_col(fill = splstyle::base_color, width = 0.8) q <- q + lemon::facet_rep_wrap(~location_code, repeat.tick.labels = "y", ncol=4) q <- q + scale_fill_fhi("Location",palette="primary") q <- q + scale_x_discrete("Isoweek") q <- q + scale_y_continuous("Number of reported cases",   breaks = splstyle::pretty_breaks(5),   expand = expansion(mult = c(0, 0.1)) ) q <- q + labs(title = "Epicurve from 2018-01-01 to 2018-02-20") q <- q + labs(caption = fhi_caption()) q <- q + theme_fhi_lines_horizontal() q <- q + splstyle::set_x_axis_vertical() q

title: Epicurves
text: Sometimes like add colours differentiate different variables. can done fill attribute.
code: pd <- w[location_code %in% "county03"] pd[, cum_n := cumsum(N)]  pd[, value_left := N] pd[, value_right := cum_n]  max_left <- max(pd$value_left) max_right <- max(pd$value_right)  # increase the space in the y-axis max_left <- max(c(max_left, 5)) max_right <- max(c(max_right, 5))  pd[, scaled_value_right := value_right / max_right * max_left]  q <- ggplot(pd, aes(x = isoyearweek)) q <- q + geom_col(   mapping = aes(     y = value_left,     fill = "The fill variable",   ),   width = 0.8   ) q <- q + geom_line(   mapping = aes(     y = scaled_value_right,     group = 1,     color = "The color variable"   ),   lwd = 2   ) q <- q + scale_x_discrete("Isoweek") q <- q + scale_y_continuous("Number of reported cases",   breaks = splstyle::pretty_breaks(5),   expand = expansion(mult = c(0, 0.1)),   sec.axis = sec_axis(     name = "Cumulative number of reported cases\n",     ~ . * max_right / max_left,     breaks = splstyle::pretty_breaks(5),     labels = splstyle::format_nor   ) ) q <- q + splstyle::scale_fill_fhi("Fill", palette = "primary") q <- q + splstyle::scale_color_fhi("Color", palette = "posneg") q <- q + labs(title = "Epicurve from 2018-01-01 to 2018-02-20") q <- q + labs(caption = fhi_caption()) q <- q + splstyle::theme_fhi_lines_horizontal() q <- q + splstyle::set_x_axis_vertical() q

code: pd <- fhimaps::norway_nuts3_map_b2020_insert_oslo_dt data <- unique(pd[,c("location_code")]) suppressWarnings(data[,category:=rep(c("Good","Normal","Neutral","Bad","Very Bad"),each=4)[1:.N]]) data[,category_with_missing:=category] data[1,category_with_missing:="Missing"] data[,category:=factor(category,levels=c("Good","Normal","Neutral","Bad","Very Bad"))] data[,category_with_missing:=factor(category_with_missing,levels=c("Good","Normal","Neutral","Bad","Very Bad","Missing"))] pd[data,on="location_code",category:=category] pd[data,on="location_code",category_with_missing:=category_with_missing] q <- ggplot() q <- q + geom_polygon(data = pd, aes( x = long, y = lat, group = group, fill=category), color="black", size=0.25) q <- q + coord_quickmap() q <- q + splstyle::scale_fill_fhi("Category",palette = "map_seq_complete", direction = 1) q <- q + labs(title="Palette: 'map_seq_complete'") q <- q + theme_void() q q <- ggplot() q <- q + geom_polygon(data = pd, aes( x = long, y = lat, group = group, fill=category), color="black", size=0.25) q <- q + coord_quickmap() q <- q + splstyle::scale_fill_fhi("Category",palette = "map_div_complete", direction = 1) q <- q + labs(title="Palette: 'map_div_complete'") q <- q + theme_void() q q <- ggplot() q <- q + geom_polygon(data = pd, aes( x = long, y = lat, group = group, fill=category_with_missing), color="black", size=0.25) q <- q + coord_quickmap() q <- q + splstyle::scale_fill_fhi("Category",palette = "map_seq_missing", direction = 1) q <- q + labs(title="Palette: 'map_seq_missing'") q <- q + theme_void() q q <- ggplot() q <- q + geom_polygon(data = pd, aes( x = long, y = lat, group = group, fill=category_with_missing), color="black", size=0.25) q <- q + coord_quickmap() q <- q + splstyle::scale_fill_fhi("Category",palette = "map_div_missing", direction = 1) q <- q + labs(title="Palette: 'map_div_missing'") q <- q + theme_void() q

title: Plot with scaled y-axis
code: library(ggplot2) library(splstyle) #> splstyle 2022.7.28 #> https://docs.sykdomspulsen.no/splstyle library(spltime) #> spltime 2022.4.21 #> https://docs.sykdomspulsen.no/spltime library(magrittr)

title: Plot with scaled y-axis
text: simulate fictional data demonstration. simulate 2-year weekly data mortality cases two locations, county county B. count cases follow Poisson distribution different \(\lambda\). county \(\lambda_{observed} = 1000, \lambda_{expected} = 500\). county B \(\lambda_{observed} = 1000, \lambda_{expected} = 2000\). First visualise fictional observed death 2 years.
code: yrwk_19_20 <- fhidata::world_dates_isoyearweek[year %in% c(2019, 2020),                                                .(year, yrwk)]  simulate_case <- function(yrwk_df, lambda_expected, lambda_observed, location_code){   nweeks <- nrow(yrwk_df)   n_observed <- rpois(nweeks, lambda_observed)   n_expected <- rpois(nweeks, lambda_expected)    df <- data.frame(deaths_n_observed = n_observed,                    deaths_n_expected = n_expected,                    location_code = location_code)   df <- cbind(yrwk_df, df)   return(df) }   set.seed(1) df_loc1 <- simulate_case(yrwk_df = yrwk_19_20,                          lambda_expected = 1000,                          lambda_observed = 500,                          location_code = "county_A") df_loc2 <- simulate_case(yrwk_df = yrwk_19_20,                          lambda_expected = 1000,                          lambda_observed = 2000,                          location_code = "county_B")  dd <- rbind(df_loc1, df_loc2) dd #>      year    yrwk deaths_n_observed deaths_n_expected location_code #>   1: 2019 2019-01               485               998      county_A #>   2: 2019 2019-02               529               978      county_A #>   3: 2019 2019-03               528              1047      county_A #>   4: 2019 2019-04               509               984      county_A #>   5: 2019 2019-05               465              1016      county_A #>  ---                                                                #> 206: 2020 2020-49              2027               980      county_B #> 207: 2020 2020-50              2024              1007      county_B #> 208: 2020 2020-51              2040               986      county_B #> 209: 2020 2020-52              2119               972      county_B #> 210: 2020 2020-53              1991              1037      county_B # separate the yrwk string to produce week id  dd$week <- spltime::isoyearweek_to_isoweek_n(dd$yrwk) dd$year <- as.factor(dd$year)  # plot cases q <- ggplot(dd, aes(x = week, y = deaths_n_observed, color = year)) q <- q + geom_line(lwd = 1.3) q <- q + facet_wrap(~ location_code, nrow = 2, scale = 'free') # use fhi themes q <- q + splstyle::theme_fhi_basic(10) q <- q + splstyle::scale_color_fhi("", palette = "primary", direction = -1) q <- q + splstyle::theme_fhi_lines_horizontal() q <- q + guides(color = guide_legend(reverse = FALSE)) q <- q + labs(title = "Observed deaths (simulated data)",                x = "Week",               y = "Number of death cases") q

title: Plot with scaled y-axis
text: can compute cumulative excess mortality per year, well ratio cumulative observed deaths expected deaths location, year.

previous_headings: Example: excess mortality > Cumulative excess mortality and ratio
title: Plot with scaled y-axis
text: plot ratio original scale. Need format y-axis using format_nor_num_2 2 digits.
code: max_val <- max(abs(dd$cum_excess_ratio)) q <- ggplot(dd, aes(x=week, y=cum_excess_ratio, color = year)) q <- q + geom_line(lwd = 1.3) q <- q + geom_hline(yintercept = 1, lty = 2) q <- q + facet_wrap(~ location_code, nrow = 1, scale = 'free')  q <- q + splstyle::theme_fhi_basic(10) q <- q + splstyle::scale_color_fhi("", palette = "primary", direction = -1) q <- q + guides(color = guide_legend(reverse = FALSE)) q <- q + scale_y_continuous(breaks = splstyle::pretty_breaks(8),                             labels = format_nor_num_2,                             lim = c(0, max_val*1.2)) q <- q + labs(title = "Ratio of cumulative observed versus expected mortality (simulated data)",                x = "Week",               y = "Ratio of cumulative mortality") q

previous_headings: Example: excess mortality > Cumulative excess mortality and ratio
title: Plot with scaled y-axis
text: Now can plot log-2 scale taking y = log2(cum_excess_ratio), still keeping y-axis original scale. way visual distance ratio 1 even though actual distances \(0.5 (|0.5-1|)\) \(1 (|2-1|)\) respectively.
code: max_val <- max(abs(log2(dd$cum_excess_ratio))) q <- ggplot(dd, aes(x=week, y=log2(cum_excess_ratio), color = year)) q <- q + geom_line(lwd = 1.3) q <- q + geom_hline(yintercept = 0, lty = 2) q <- q + facet_wrap(~ location_code, scale = 'free')  q <- q + splstyle::theme_fhi_basic(10) q <- q + splstyle::scale_color_fhi("", palette = "primary", direction = -1) q <- q + guides(color = guide_legend(reverse = FALSE)) q <- q + scale_y_continuous(breaks = splstyle::pretty_breaks(9),                             labels = format_nor_invlog2_2,                             lim = c(-max_val, max_val)) q <- q + labs(title = "Ratio of cumulative observed versus expected mortality (simulated data)",                x = "Week",               y = "Ratio of cumulative mortality")  q

title: Introduction to splstyle
text: Make sure dataset contains days/weeks (.e. can days/weeks 0 cases) Use q <- q + splstyle::theme_fhi_lines_horizontal() Use q <- q + geom_col(fill = splstyle::base_color, width = 0.8) scale_y_continuous use breaks = splstyle::pretty_breaks(5) scale_y_continuous use expand = expansion(mult = c(0, 0.1)) x-axis cramped, make labels vertical q <- q + splstyle::set_x_axis_vertical() Say data extracted q <- q + labs(caption = "Data extracted 2018-02-20") multiple geographical areas: - Use q <- q + lemon::facet_rep_wrap(~location_code, repeat.tick.labels = "y")

code: q <- ggplot(d, aes(x = date, y = N)) q <- q + geom_col(fill = splstyle::base_color, width = 0.8) q <- q + lemon::facet_rep_wrap(~location_code, repeat.tick.labels = "y") q <- q + splstyle::scale_fill_fhi("Location",palette="primary") q <- q + scale_x_date("Date") q <- q + scale_y_continuous("Number of reported cases",   breaks = splstyle::pretty_breaks(5),   expand = expansion(mult = c(0, 0.1)) ) q <- q + labs(title = "Epicurve from 2018-01-01 to 2018-02-20") q <- q + labs(caption = fhi_caption()) q <- q + splstyle::theme_fhi_lines_horizontal() q <- q + splstyle::set_x_axis_vertical() q q <- ggplot(d, aes(x = isoyearweek, y = N)) q <- q + geom_col(fill = splstyle::base_color, width = 0.8) q <- q + lemon::facet_rep_wrap(~location_code, repeat.tick.labels = "y", ncol=4) q <- q + scale_fill_fhi("Location",palette="primary") q <- q + scale_x_discrete("Isoweek") q <- q + scale_y_continuous("Number of reported cases",   breaks = splstyle::pretty_breaks(5),   expand = expansion(mult = c(0, 0.1)) ) q <- q + labs(title = "Epicurve from 2018-01-01 to 2018-02-20") q <- q + labs(caption = fhi_caption()) q <- q + theme_fhi_lines_horizontal() q <- q + splstyle::set_x_axis_vertical() q

title: Introduction to splstyle
text: Sometimes like add colours differentiate different variables. can done fill attribute.
code: pd <- w[location_code %in% "county03"] pd[, cum_n := cumsum(N)]  pd[, value_left := N] pd[, value_right := cum_n]  max_left <- max(pd$value_left) max_right <- max(pd$value_right)  # increase the space in the y-axis max_left <- max(c(max_left, 5)) max_right <- max(c(max_right, 5))  pd[, scaled_value_right := value_right / max_right * max_left]  q <- ggplot(pd, aes(x = isoyearweek)) q <- q + geom_col(   mapping = aes(     y = value_left,     fill = "The fill variable",   ),   width = 0.8   ) q <- q + geom_line(   mapping = aes(     y = scaled_value_right,     group = 1,     color = "The color variable"   ),   lwd = 2   ) q <- q + scale_x_discrete("Isoweek") q <- q + scale_y_continuous("Number of reported cases",   breaks = splstyle::pretty_breaks(5),   expand = expansion(mult = c(0, 0.1)),   sec.axis = sec_axis(     name = "Cumulative number of reported cases\n",     ~ . * max_right / max_left,     breaks = splstyle::pretty_breaks(5),     labels = splstyle::format_nor   ) ) q <- q + splstyle::scale_fill_fhi("Fill", palette = "primary") q <- q + splstyle::scale_color_fhi("Color", palette = "posneg") q <- q + labs(title = "Epicurve from 2018-01-01 to 2018-02-20") q <- q + labs(caption = fhi_caption()) q <- q + splstyle::theme_fhi_lines_horizontal() q <- q + splstyle::set_x_axis_vertical() q
